title: 106_hr15
content: The Act may be cited as the "Otay Mountain Wilderness Act of 1999". The Congress finds that the Otay Mountain region in California is a pristine location known for its unique plants and plays a critical role in biodiversity conservation. The area also faces challenges related to illegal immigration and fire management due to its proximity to the international border. Certain public lands in the California Desert District are designated as wilderness, known as the Otay Mountain Wilderness, in line with the Wilderness Act. The area covers approximately 18,500 acres and is part of the National Wilderness Preservation System. A map and legal description are provided for reference. The Secretary must file a map and legal description for the Wilderness Area with the Senate and House Committees. The map and description will be available for public inspection and any errors can be corrected. The southern boundary of the Wilderness Area must be 100 feet north of the trail depicted on the map. The Wilderness Area is located 100 feet north of the trail on the map and is also at least 100 feet away from the US-Mexico border. SEC. 5. Wilderness areas in Southern Otay Mountain and Western Otay Mountain have been adequately studied for designation, no longer subject to management requirements for preservation. SEC. 6. Administration of wilderness area. The Wilderness Area shall be administered by the Secretary in accordance with the Wilderness Act, with adjustments for effective dates and agency references. Due to its proximity to the US-Mexico border, management actions like drug interdiction and wildland fire protection are necessary and will continue. The Wilderness Area will be managed in accordance with the Wilderness Act, with adjustments for effective dates and agency references. Management actions like drug interdiction and wildland fire protection will continue as long as they comply with the Wilderness Act and conditions set by the Secretary. SEC. 7. FURTHER ACQUISITIONS: Any lands acquired by the United States after this Act's enactment become part of the Wilderness Area and must be managed accordingly. SEC. 8. NO BUFFER ZONES: The Act does not create protective perimeters or buffer zones around the Wilderness Area. SEC. 9. DEFINITIONS. SEC. 9. DEFINITIONS. The term "public lands" refers to lands as defined in the Federal Land Policy and Management Act of 1976. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of the Interior. "Wilderness Area" refers to the Otay Mountain Wilderness designated by section 3.
